bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Jefferson Randolph Kean, October 14, 1949

div1.p: Hench appreciates the letters from Sternberg and Finlay. He hopes to see the Wood papers the next time he is in Washington, D.C.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Jefferson Randolph Kean, October 14, 1949
div1.opener:
October 14, 1949
General Jefferson R. Kean
2804 N. Street, N. W.
Georgetown
Washington, D. C.
My dear General Kean:
div1.p:
I have, indeed, been busy since I returned home. It was so
nice to see you and Mrs. Kean. I am delighted to receive the letters
from Sternberg and also the one from Finlay. These will be nice
additions to our collection and will be kept safely together. All of
these important letters I have locked in a safe.

I had a very pleasant day at the Congressional Library with the
Director and Assistant Director of Manuscripts. I shall be in
Washington again on January 4 to attend an all day meeting of the
United States Public Health Service Committee on Cortisone and Related
Substances and then shall speak that evening before the Surgeon General
Staff Meeting at Walter Reed Hospital. It may be possible for me to
stay over an extra day and I hope, as a result of the combined efforts
of the Head of the Manuscript Division and of General McCoy, that I may
be able to see the Wood Papers.

Because of the numerous interruptions at work here, I will not be
able to attend a Walter Reed Medical Meeting. I would very much
appreciate it if you would telephone Colonel Siler to that effect.
If there is any preliminary help that I can give on the matters mentioned
in my letter to be brought before the Board of Managers of the Walter Reed
Medical Association, please let me know.

I am sending you by parcel post a package of about one hundred reprints
on the article published in “Hygeia” and twenty-five or more reprints of
the article from the Proceedings covering the meeting held in Washington
last year. I have a smaller number of each available for your son but I
carelessly lost his address. If you will kindly send his address to me, I
will be glad to send him these reprints at once.
div1.closer: Affectionately, P. S. Hench, M. D. PSH:mfm
